transcription.text: [ Music ]
[ Applause ]
[ Silence ]
>> Okay. So, hi everyone.
My name is Augusto.
I have been working with the Reding Project for the past two years.
And today I'm going to present to you guys what we have done for the past year
and what is included in developer preview.
So, for those of you that doesn't know,
Reding is an scalability solution that we have built for Ethereum,
and it can be scaled to a bit of million transactions per second.
Okay? So, I'm going to give you a quick agenda of my talk.
This is going to be split in two parts, and the first ten minutes,
I'm going to talk about Reding, and the second half, for the last ten minutes,
we're going to talk about the micro-rediting.
So, for the Reding, we're going to talk about the Reding APIs.
Reding is exposing an HTTP RESTful API so that you guys can use
to build applications on top of it.
And the goal of my presentation today is to explain to all of you
how you can use Reding to build apps.
And to that regard, we're going to talk about how can you join the Reding Network.
Once you have joined the Reding Network, how can you make transfers,
and how can you react to transfers that you know it has received?
So, that's agenda.
So, first things first, the setup phase.
So, Reding is an open-source project.
We have it available on the GitHub, and under the release pages,
we have an app image that any of you guys can use in Cloud Reding.
It's an executable, you can just download and start running in your machine.
Right now, Reding only works on Linux.
We are fixing some issues with Mac OS in a week in the end.
In the next release, you should be able to use Reding on Mac OS 2.
For the moment, we don't support Windows.
And also, I once pointed out that Reding is not an Ethereum node.
Reding is a separate process that communicates with an Ethereum node.
So, to use Reding, you will also need an Ethereum node running on the machine
that you're working on.
And for that, for the Reding process to communicate with the Ethereum node,
you will need to enable JSON RPC because that's the current interface
that we use to communicate.
So, once you have this setup, then let's decide how to talk about how to use Reding.
So, the first thing that you want to do once you have Reding installed
is to connect to the Reding network.
And the Reding network in the Reding process, we have two APIs to connect to the network.
The first one that I'm going to present to you guys,
it's the endpoint for connections.
This is an automatic way of setting up channels that Reding is going to manage for you guys.
And the goal of this endpoint is for you guys to configure Reding,
telling how much Reding should use to manage and open channels with the network.
So, our goal is to never start using the tokens for that count that's configured with Reding
without the user permission, and you need to use that endpoint
telling us how much funds do you want to use.
Once you have used the endpoint, Reding knows which funds you want to use,
how much of it you're allowing Reding to use,
and then Reding will manage channels for you on your behalf.
So, that's the automatic channel management.
You can use it with the put verb in the API1 connections endpoint.
If you don't want to use the automatic management, you can open channels by hand.
That's done by the put verb in the channels endpoint.
And that's basically the same thing, but you're going to manage the channels on your own.
You just specify everything that you want to use in the JSON
that's going to be sent to the server, and the Reding will use the data
that you provide to it to open channels.
So, everything like the token address, the amount of funds,
the target node that you're connecting to, it's defined by you.
So, these are the two APIs for connecting to the network.
Once you have connected to a network, you have channels available to be managed.
The way that you can manage the channels open with Reding is by using the patch keyword,
the patch verb for the HTTP.
And you can then patch the current status of your channel
and increase the deposit if you want to have more funds to make more transfers
or you can change the state of the channel by closing it.
Once you close the channel, Reding will automatically wait for the settlement period.
That's the period that we have for dispute resolution.
And once the dispute is over, Reding will withdraw your tokens from the channel
using the proofs that was available by both of the parties in the channel.
So, that's everything that we need to know on how to connect to the Reding network.
And once you have connected to the Reding network and you have channels opened,
you can make transfers.
So, to make transfers, you can use the post-verb with the transfers end point
and that end point is going to expose you guys,
#TimeLock mediated transfers.
#TimeLock are a nice abstraction that we can use
and that makes for a concealable and an expirable transfers.
So, that's the best kind of transfers that we have that expose the nicest error model
for people to build applications on top.
For making transfers, there is an important detail that Reding is not part of your application.
Reding is a server that's running on a computer that you're going to communicate
through REST APIs.
You need to provide some knowledge or some application-specific data to Reding
so that both of the nodes, the ones that's paying, the ones that's receiving the payment,
know what the payment is regarding to you.
So, let's assume that you're building an e-commerce application
or something that needs to make a payment.
For the e-commerce application, you can give an edging fire to a cart
and use that identifier as part of the transfer.
So, that's the way that a declined application can tell the note that's being paid
and what the payment is about.
Currently, we don't allow, in the current version of the API,
to send arbitrary data that may change in the future.
That's just the current transport that we have available.
Okay, so once you've made transfers, that's two parts of the agenda.
The last thing that you want to do is react to receiving payments
for the Reding network.
And that can be done by pulling for events in the Reding node.
We are just providing a simple API for the moment with pulling in the future view.
We will add maybe long pulling or different transport that can push events for you.
But the way that you can react to payments is by watching for the event transfer received.
That event is emitted every time that you receive a payment and then you can react to it.
And that event will have the identifier and the token and the amount of the transfer that you received.
So, that's everything that you need to know about the endpoints available in Reding.
And with that, you can build applications on top of it that make payments using the Reding network.
So, if you want your test, Reding, we currently are doing a developer preview.
So, it's not available on the mainnet, it's only available on the Robson test network.
And on the Robson test network, we have deployed all the Reding smart contracts
and including the Reding test token.
And with the Reding test token, we have made available a mint method
that you can use to maintain yourself some test tokens and use that test token to make payments in the test network.
So, once you have used the Reding test token to get yourself some tokens in the test network,
you can connect to some nodes.
And here is a node that you may try to use.
We have made it, it's a programable node that's just going to reply to the transfers that you make to it
with a transfer of the same amount and same token in the case of the Reding test token.
And if you want to connect to the test network using the automatic connection endpoint,
we have made available a test network with 100 Reding nodes.
So, when you use the automatic connection management,
you're probably going to connect to one of the nodes and everything is going to work as expected.
So, these details, I'm not going to focus too much on them, they are all available in documentation.
And as an example of an application built on top of Reding, we have built the web UI.
So, the web UI is one of the UIs that we have available for the Reding project,
and the web UI is available in our source code that you can just find in the UI folder
and that it's built using these endpoints that I have showed you guys.
So, that's everything that I have to show you.
That's how you need to know to build applications on top of Reding.
And if you want more additional details on the format of the JSON files,
the response and the different verbs are different endpoints that we have available,
you can go to the Reding network with the docs and we have much more information there,
including how to deploy your own tokens and use a different test network if you don't want to use the Rops and Test network.
So, with that, I'm just going to leave for Loredenum that's going to talk about micro-railing.
[Applause]
[Applause]
[Applause]
Hello. I'm Loredenum, one of the developers that contributed to micro-railing.
I'm going to tell you today what is micro-railing for what you can use it,
and I'll also show you a small live demo of a token-fueled robot.
So, what is micro-railing?
Micro-railing is a robust off-chain payment channel framework,
and it's easy to use off-the-shelf.
It is good for 80% of the use cases that someone can think of when they are thinking of using Raiden for their own service or business.
It is a unidirectional many-to-one implementation, which means we don't need to think about routing issues
and incentivizing fees for users who have open channels and want to share them with others.
This is why we have off-chain transactions that are fast and free.
Micro-railing is available now on the COVID test net,
and will be available on the main net by the end of November, which is by the end of this month.
So, what can you build with micro-railing?
For human consumption, the most straightforward use case is paper use,
and we already have two demos, one with a fortune cookie paywall that is online now,
and an unpleasant alternate world where you pay for Wikipedia.
But the most interesting use case is the machine-to-machine micro-payments that you can do.
So, basically, if you have an API that you want to monetize, you can use micro-railing.
From utilities to data storage to scheduled API queries,
and we already have a machine-to-machine demo where we query the price of Ether in US dollars each second.
And you can see the entire lifecycle of a channel from opening to depositing new tokens,
to closing it, and also see the off-chain micro-payments.
How are they created and received?
And now for the live demo.
I want you to bear with me a little bit.
So, this is Robo, and I hope there's a camera.
Robo has his own Ethereum address,
and he uses micro-railing to be paid in tokens for his work.
We already have an account here with Robo.
This is the JavaScript client, and we used Node-Reds for this dashboard.
And we can see that we already have an open channel with a deposit of 50 tokens,
and a channel balance of two tokens, which means that we already paid Robo two tokens for his services.
We have a remote control for him, and the buttons for forward back, right, left, back left, and back right
are connected to a micro-payment endpoint.
This is the micro-rated server, and we can see that the JavaScript client has signed a balance proof for us,
and that instantly the micro-rated server has received that payment.
[Applause]
Sorry, I don't have enough time to show you everything.
You can see that the balance has increased with every press of the button.
You can, of course, do this by timing the robot or measuring the distance,
but this was, I mean, we implemented this very, very fast in a couple of days,
and it's not that complicated.
Okay. What we can do when we remain without tokens is go to our account and deposit more,
and this is an on-chain transaction.
So what you've seen until now are off-chain micro-payments,
and to verify this, we can go to Etherscan and see that the transaction will be included in the box shortly,
and we can also see the micro-rated server registering the event for depositing new tokens.
Of course, when we've finished everything with Robo, we can close the channel,
and again, we can verify in Etherscan that this is an on-chain transaction,
and the micro-rated server has also received this.
Okay. Going back to the presentation.
The code for this, for the examples are in the micro-rated repositories,
under micro-rated and micro-rated examples, and for the robot, the token-hungry car,
we will link it in the readme, but for now, the JSON for setting up the Node-RED dashboard
is in one of my personal repositories. So to recap a bit, you can open a channel on-chain.
You can deposit tokens on-chain. You can close a channel on-chain,
but the essence of micro-rated are the micro-payments that are done off-chain, fast, and free,
between opening and closing a channel.
I'll try to make it fast, a simple explanation of how it works.
The sender and the receiver both keep copies of the channel data,
which is receiver and sender Ethereum addresses, the block number at which the channel has been created,
and the current balance, because we've seen that the balance increases,
so it's the last status. And also the receiver has the last balance proof received from the sender.
What is the last balance proof? It's basically a message signed by the sender,
which contains the current balance, the block number, and the receiver's address.
The micro-payment works like this. The sender sends all this data along with his signature to the receiver.
The receiver provides the resource and also saves this signed balance proof.
We also support the ERC 223 in work standard, along with the ERC 24, opening a channel and the positing tokens,
because the ERC 223 offers us the possibility of consuming less gas,
because we only do one transaction instead of two for approving and opening a channel.
I'm going to skip this very fast. Maybe tell you a little bit about closing a channel,
and we can do this. We can find ourselves in three states.
One is a cooperative close, which is the best-case scenario, when the sender queries the receiver for a closing signature,
and then closes the channel himself by providing his balance signature and the receiver's closing signature.
And everything is well and good. If anything goes wrong, we have a challenge period where the channel can be closed by the receiver
by providing that last balance proof saved.
In conclusion, micro-written is ready to use. It is the go-to solution for frequent, fast, and free ERC 2-N2 token-based off-chain micro-payments
on the Ethereum blockchain. And don't forget, robots also want crypto.
[Applause]
Thank you, Laura, Donna.
[Applause]
[Music]
[buzzing]
